You said:
how do I run an http server in the folder?
ChatGPT said:

To preview the site properly, your browser needs to load the Markdown and JSON files over HTTP rather than the file:// protocol. The easiest way to do this is to run a small HTTP server from the directory where the files are located. You don’t need to install any third‑party software if you have Python installed—Python ships with a simple server in its standard library. Here’s how to use it:

  1. Open a terminal or command prompt and navigate to the folder where your extracted website files live (use cd /path/to/folder).

  2. Once you’re in the correct folder, run the following command:

    bash
    python3 -m http.server

    This launches a server on port 8000 and serves the current directoryrealpython.com. You’ll see output similar to “Serving HTTP on 0.0.0.0 port 8000…”.

  3. Open a browser and visit http://localhost:8000/. You should see a directory listing; click index.html to load the site. All the dynamic content (news, publications, hero, research) will now load correctly because it’s being fetched over HTTP.

If port 8000 is in use, you can choose a different port by appending it to the command (e.g., python3 -m http.server 8080)realpython.com. On Windows the command is the same (python -m http.server), but ensure you’re using your installed Python version. This approach will let you test the site locally before uploading it to a hosting service.

🧪 How to Test If Markdown Is Failing to Load

Open your browser’s Developer Tools (usually by pressing F12 or Cmd+Option+I on Mac), go to the Console and Network tabs.

  • In the Console: look for any red errors related to fetch or marked.

  • In the Network tab: look for 404 or failed requests to data/hero.md, data/research.md, etc.

If you see something like:

bash
GET http://localhost:8000/data/hero.md 404 (Not Found)

…it means the file isn’t in the right place, or the folder structure was extracted incorrectly.

🛠️ Fixes

  • If you extracted the ZIP and the folder was named something like new_website_v2/new_website/, make sure you're serving from the inner new_website/ folder.

    • Navigate into that with cd new_website_v2/new_website

    • Then run: python3 -m http.server

  • Make sure the .md files are not renamed with .txt or hidden by your system (especially on Windows or macOS).

If you'd like, you can upload a screenshot of your browser showing the error or the file listing, and I can help debug exactly what's going wrong. Or tell me what you see in the Console or Network tab.

You said:
Is this markdown?
ChatGPT said:

Not quite — the layout I gave you uses HTML embedded inside a Markdown file, which is fully valid in most Markdown renderers used in GitHub Pages and Jekyll-based sites like yours.

Why HTML-in-Markdown?

  • Standard Markdown can’t handle complex layout like side-by-side images + text (like your publication card with a thumbnail).

  • Markdown is great for basic formatting (headings, bold, italics, lists, links), but not layout control.

  • HTML is allowed inside .md files, and it’s the best way to create custom layouts, especially for your use case.

TL;DR

✅ Yes, you can still use .md files for everything.
✅ The structure I gave will render properly in your site.
✅ You can keep all your publications in publications.md.
✅ Just add that HTML block for each paper.

What you're seeing is HTML, not Markdown. Your current academicpages template is written in HTML for finer control over layout, styling, and interactivity (e.g., with thumbnail images, two-column designs, hover effects, etc). ✅ Use HTML Blocks (inside your Markdown)

GitHub Pages and Jekyll allow inline HTML within Markdown files. So you can embed HTML like this directly into your news.md or publications.md file, and it will render properly:

html
<div class="pub-entry">
  <img src="/images/depict-thumb.png" alt="DEPICT thumbnail" class="pub-thumb">
  <div class="pub-info">
    <div class="pub-title">
      <a href="#">DEPICT: Diffusion Enabled Permutation Importance for Image Classification Tasks</a>
    </div>
    <div class="pub-authors">
      <strong>Sarah Jabbour</strong>, Gregory Kondas, Ella Kazerooni, Michael W. Sjoding, David Fouhey, Jenna Wiens
    </div>
    <div class="pub-venue"><em>ECCV, 2024</em></div>
    <div class="pub-description">
      Extends permutation feature importance to images by using text-conditioned diffusion to generate dataset-level explanations for image classifiers.
    </div>
    <div class="pub-links">
      <a href="#">paper</a> / <a href="#">website</a> / <a href="#">code</a><br>
      <span class="pub-press"><a href="#">press coverage</a></span>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

🔍 Problem Recap

From your screenshot, it looks like the browser is showing raw HTML inside a Markdown-rendered page — meaning the HTML is being displayed as code instead of being interpreted and rendered visually.

You pasted something like this into your publications.md file:

md
<div class="pub-entry">
  <img src="..." alt="..." class="pub-thumb">
  ...
</div>

But instead of rendering it visually, your browser is showing it as literal code, which suggests:

🔧 Root Cause: Your Markdown File is Escaping HTML

Most likely, your publications.md file is being processed with a Markdown engine that escapes HTML or disables raw HTML rendering. This can happen in two common ways:

1. Your site's Markdown processor is not allowing raw HTML

Some Jekyll/GitHub Pages setups (like academicpages) disable raw HTML in .md files by default for safety. You’ll see this behavior if:

  • You're using a layout like page that sanitizes or restricts HTML.

  • Or if kramdown or markdownify settings are stripping HTML from Markdown in your layout file.

2. You’re writing inside a YAML block (e.g., news.yml or _data)

If the publication content is going into a .yml file instead of a .md, then yes — HTML will be shown as-is.

✅ Confirm What's Happening

Can you check whether:

  1. Your publications.md file has a frontmatter that looks like this?

    yaml
    ---
layout: page
title: "Recent Publications"
permalink: /publications/
---

  2. And in your _layouts/page.html, there is a line like this:

    liquid
    {{ content }}

    — which would allow raw HTML inside Markdown.

If instead you see:

liquid
{{ content | markdownify }}

Then raw HTML gets escaped, which causes exactly what you're seeing.

🛠️ How to Fix It

✅ Option 1: Make Sure {{ content }} is used in layout

  1. Go to _layouts/page.html

  2. Look for:

    liquid
    {{ content | markdownify }}

  3. Replace with:

    liquid
    {{ content }}

This will allow raw HTML to render properly inside your .md files.

✅ Option 2: Switch to .html instead of .md

If you want full control, you can rename publications.md → publications.html and move your HTML there with the same frontmatter:

html
---
layout: page
title: "Recent Publications"
permalink: /publications/
---

<!-- Now paste your HTML here -->
<div class="pub-entry">
  ...
</div>

Then you can do anything you want with layout.

ok, now I think I'd like to "widen" how much space is taken up on the screen. everything is squished into a narrow column
ChatGPT said:

To widen the layout so your publication section doesn’t look so squished into a narrow column, you’ll need to adjust the CSS that controls the page width. Your website is likely using a max-width constraint on a container or wrapper <div> that centers and restricts the content width (e.g., max-width: 800px;).

✅ Here’s How to Widen It

Step 1: Locate the container class

Look in your HTML layout or template file (commonly default.html, index.html, or a layout file if you're using Jekyll or similar). Find the main wrapper <div> — it might look like:

html
<div class="container">

Step 2: Edit your CSS

Find the corresponding CSS rule (in style.css, main.css, or _sass if using Jekyll).

Change from something like this:

css
.container {
  max-width: 800px;
  margin: 0 auto;
  padding: 20px;
}

To this:

css
.container {
  max-width: 1200px;  /* or try 100% for full width */
  margin: 0 auto;
  padding: 20px;
}

Optional: Make publication cards more spacious

If you want more horizontal spacing between thumbnail and text (in your pub-card class), you can tweak the layout:

css
.pub-card {
  display: flex;
  align-items: flex-start;
  margin-bottom: 40px;
  gap: 24px; /* increases space between image and text */
}

.pub-thumb {
  width: 160px;
  flex-shrink: 0;
  border-radius: 6px;
}

.pub-info {
  flex: 1;
}

💡 Pro Tip

If you're using GitHub Pages + academicpages, the container width is often controlled in:

  • _sass/_layout.scss

  • or directly in assets/css/main.scss

Search for max-width or .container and bump it up from 800px to 1200px or 90%.

You said:
im trying to quickly iterate on the websiteby refreshing the html page in google chrome as I edit, but I think bc of cookies its just not updating
ChatGPT said:

If your HTML edits aren't showing up when you refresh in Chrome, it's almost certainly a caching issue, not cookies. Here’s how to quickly force updates while iterating:

✅ Recommended Fix: Use Hard Reload + Clear Cache

In Chrome:

  1. Right-click the refresh button 🔁 (next to the URL bar).

  2. Select “Empty Cache and Hard Reload”.

This clears cached versions of CSS, JS, and HTML and forces a fresh load.

⚡ Faster Iteration Tips

Here are more options to speed up your dev loop:

1. Disable Cache While Dev Tools is Open

  • Open DevTools (Cmd+Opt+I on Mac or F12 / Ctrl+Shift+I on Windows).

  • Go to the Network tab.

  • Check ✅ "Disable cache" at the top.

  • Keep DevTools open — it will now always fetch fresh files on reload.

2. Use a Local HTTP Server

If you aren't already, run a local server instead of opening the HTML file directly in your browser. Browsers behave more predictably with servers.

Here’s how:

bash
# In your project folder:
python3 -m http.server 8000

Then go to: http://localhost:8000

🧼 Bonus: Clear Site Cache Manually

If needed:

  • Go to Chrome → Settings → Privacy → Clear browsing data

  • Or go to chrome://settings/siteData and clear cache for just your site.

Let me know if you want help setting up a better hot-reload setup (like live-server or vite) for even faster updates.

You said:
I am already using a local http server
ChatGPT said:

Great — since you’re already using a local HTTP server, here’s what’s likely going wrong and how to force your browser to show the latest version on every refresh:

✅ Fix: Disable Cache While DevTools Is Open

  1. Open Chrome DevTools

    • Cmd + Option + I (Mac)

    • Ctrl + Shift + I (Windows/Linux)

  2. Go to the Network tab.

  3. Check the box: ✅ Disable cache
    (Only works while DevTools is open!)

  4. Refresh your page (Cmd + R or Ctrl + R).

This ensures that your browser never caches CSS, HTML, or JS while you’re editing locally.

🧪 Confirm What’s Stale

To double-check which file is being cached:

  • In DevTools > Network tab → Refresh the page

  • Click on the name of your .html or .css file

  • Look at the “Headers” tab → under Response Headers, look for:

    pgsql
    (from disk cache)

    or

    pgsql
    (from memory cache)

If you see that, you know it’s not fetching a fresh version.

🔁 Bonus: Use live-server for Instant Reload

You can get even faster feedback using live-server, which automatically reloads when you save.

To install:

bash
npm install -g live-server

Then run:

bash
live-server

It’ll open a browser tab that hot-reloads on every save — perfect for editing HTML/CSS.

Let me know which setup you prefer (hard reload vs live-server) and I can tailor more tips.

How can I get my news section to have a different colored background? '
ChatGPT said:

To give your news section a different colored background, you'll want to either:

  • Add a unique class to the news section in your HTML/Markdown, and

  • Define a background color for that class in your CSS

✅ Step-by-Step Instructions

1. In your HTML/Markdown

If your site is using Markdown processed into HTML (via Jekyll or similar), you’ll want to wrap your news section like this:

html
<section class="section news-section">
  <h2>News</h2>
  <ul>
    <li><strong>Sept 2025:</strong> Gave a talk at ML4H!</li>
    <li><strong>Aug 2025:</strong> Started internship at Microsoft Research.</li>
  </ul>
</section>

If you’re using pure Markdown, you'll likely need to embed raw HTML like above (since Markdown doesn't support section-level classes natively).

2. In your CSS

Add a rule like this in your main CSS file:

css
.news-section {
  background-color: #f9f4ed;  /* light tan/cream background */
  padding: 40px 20px;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

You can choose any background color — for example:

  • #f0f4f8 → soft blue-gray

  • #f9f4ed → warm cream

  • #fff7e6 → gentle peach

  • #e8f1fa → light blue (used in your .hero)

🎨 Optional: Dark Text + Better Spacing

To ensure readability:

css
.news-section {
  background-color: #f0f4f8;
  color: #222;              /* darker text */
  padding: 40px 20px;
  margin-top: 40px;
  border-radius: 6px;
}
.news-section h2 {
  margin-top: 0;
}

You said:
how to change the font everywhere?
ChatGPT said:

To change the font everywhere on your site, you can follow these steps. I'll walk you through using a Google Fonts import, but this also works if you're hosting your own font or using system fonts.

✅ Step 1: Choose Your Fonts

You can pick two fonts:

  • Heading font: Serif like Playfair Display or DM Serif Display

  • Body font: Sans-serif like Inter, Source Sans Pro, or DM Sans

Here’s a sample pair:

  • Heading: Playfair Display

  • Body: Inter

✅ Step 2: Import the Fonts in HTML

In your main HTML file (likely index.html), in the <head> section, paste this:

html
<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter:wght@400;600&family=Playfair+Display:wght@600&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">

This loads the fonts from Google Fonts.

✅ Step 3: Apply Fonts in Your CSS

In your CSS file (e.g., style.css), add or modify the rules to apply the new fonts site-wide:

css
/* Apply Inter to all body text */
body {
  font-family: 'Inter', sans-serif;
  font-weight: 400;
  line-height: 1.75;
  color: #2C2C2C;
}

/* Apply Playfair Display to headings */
h1, h2, h3, h4, h5 {
  font-family: 'Playfair Display', serif;
  font-weight: 600;
}

🎯 Optional: Smoother Look

To make text rendering cleaner:

css
body {
  -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;
  -moz-osx-font-smoothing: grayscale;
}

Example Result

You’ll get something like this:

  • Hero heading → elegant serif (Playfair)

  • Paragraphs and links → clean modern sans (Inter)

This matches the mid-century modern look we discussed earlier.

You said:
I like the playfair display, but dont think it should be used everywhere (too harsh). What are some good design choices here for font?
ChatGPT said:

Great instincts — pairing Playfair Display with a clean, modern sans-serif for body text can create a refined and highly readable visual hierarchy. Here are a few excellent font pairings and strategies to help your site feel warmer, softer, and more polished without being harsh or overly decorative.

🧠 Guiding Design Principles

To preserve a modern but inviting feel:

  • Use Playfair Display selectively — ideal for headers or your name.

  • Pair it with a neutral sans-serif that doesn't compete visually but complements it.

  • Avoid using serif fonts for body paragraphs (too dense and less readable on web).

✨ Recommended Pairings with Playfair Display

1. Playfair Display + Source Sans Pro

  • Playfair Display for headings and hero text

  • Source Sans Pro for body text and navigation

  • 🧶 Effect: Friendly, professional, clean. Soft contrast.

2. Playfair Display + Inter

  • Inter is a modern, geometric sans-serif optimized for screen readability

  • Has excellent spacing and weight balance against Playfair

  • 🧶 Effect: Clean and tech-forward but still warm

3. Playfair Display + DM Sans

  • DM Sans is minimal and slightly rounded, which pairs beautifully with the sophistication of Playfair

  • 🧶 Effect: Soft, inviting, elegant without being stiff

4. Playfair Display + Nunito

  • Nunito is a rounded sans-serif that feels modern and bubbly

  • Best for portfolios that want to feel approachable

  • 🧶 Effect: More playful, while still clean

5. Playfair Display + Lato

  • Very versatile pairing — Lato is neutral, not too geometric or too humanist

  • 🧶 Effect: Clean, open, with just enough warmth

🌐 How to Load in Your Website

In your HTML <head>, use Google Fonts:

html
<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Playfair+Display:wght@600;700&family=Inter:wght@300;400;500&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">

Then, in your CSS:

css
body {
  font-family: 'Inter', sans-serif;
}

h1, h2, .hero-text h1 {
  font-family: 'Playfair Display', serif;
}

✅ Example: Your Site with Playfair + Inter

css
body {
  font-family: 'Inter', sans-serif;
  color: #2f2f2f;
  background-color: #fdfaf7;  /* soft tan/linen base */
}

h1, h2, h3, .hero-text h1 {
  font-family: 'Playfair Display', serif;
}

This keeps things readable but elegant — your name and section titles pop, while everything else remains smooth and modern.

Great! Since you’re using Playfair Display already (a high-contrast, old-style serif with a classic and editorial feel), and Inter (a modern, legible sans-serif), you’re already on strong footing. But here are some refined font pairing combos that can elevate your site's mid-century modern aesthetic with more personality or polish.

🔡 Font Pairing Ideas (Mid-Century Modern Friendly)

1. Playfair Display + Inter

You're already here — this combo is:

  • 📰 Elegant for headings (Playfair)

  • 📱 Readable and modern for body text (Inter)

✅ Good for: Professional + modern feel with subtle vintage notes
🔄 Could refine by using Inter Light or Inter Medium instead of Regular for a softer feel.

2. Playfair Display + Work Sans

  • Playfair Display for headers → keeps elegance

  • Work Sans for body text → softer and warmer than Inter

✅ Good for: Editorial tone + warm humanist body text
🎨 Has better roundness for mid-century softness

3. Libre Baskerville + DM Sans

  • Libre Baskerville: More grounded serif than Playfair; friendlier

  • DM Sans: Minimal geometric sans-serif with a gentle presence

✅ Good for: Softer, more welcoming vibes without losing structure

4. Cormorant Garamond + Mulish

  • Cormorant Garamond: Classic, calligraphic, less rigid than Playfair

  • Mulish: Neutral sans-serif, slightly softer than Inter

✅ Good for: Human-AI themes — elegant but not intimidating

5. EB Garamond + Space Grotesk

  • EB Garamond: Deeply classic, beautiful for quotes/headings

  • Space Grotesk: Quirky, retro-futuristic sans-serif

✅ Good for: MCM style with a hint of science/tech edge

6. DM Serif Display + Raleway

  • DM Serif Display: Bold and expressive serif

  • Raleway: Clean, modern sans-serif with a wide letter structure

✅ Good for: Personal websites that want to be bold but still readable

Bonus: Just Sans-Serif?

If you want to keep it all sans-serif but still with personality:

  • Header: Clash Grotesk, Space Grotesk, or Raleway

  • Body: Inter, Mulish, or Work Sans

✨ Mid-Century Modern Vibe Tips:

  • Look for humanist or geometric sans-serifs with round O’s and gentle contrast.

  • Pair them with serifs that feel editorial, not rigid — avoid slab-serifs unless you want a very retro look.
